instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
No liquid Damage and just stopped working.

Here is some measurement:

PPDCIM = 5.20V Drops to 4.7V (LOOP)
<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.3V (normal is 5V)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = Loop 3.4V and 3.2V after 2sec
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =3.4V and 3.2V after 2sec
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.4V


Diode Mode

L7030 = 0.449
L6995 = 0.373
F7000 - 0.412


Any hint from here?

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
"(normal is 5V)"
Yeah, when you get 20V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
1.3V is actually correct; calculate resistor divider.

You get 5V at both USB-C connectors, connected in both directions (4 tests)?
Check diode mode to ground on all power rails of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

Inspect redriver chip for any small hole on top of it...
[url]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/search?q=redriver&searchJSON=%7B%22keywords%22%3A%22redriver%22%7D[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.3V (normal is 5V) that what a mean - Normal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
You get 5V at both USB-C connectors, connected in both directions (4 tests) [B]Yes.[/B]

Diode Mode:

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> - 0.380
<CAPACITOR>C3101</CAPACITOR> - 0.195
<CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR> - 0.529
<CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR> - 0.499
<CAPACITOR>C3106</CAPACITOR> - 0.537
<CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> - 0.524

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> - 0.380
<CAPACITOR>C3201</CAPACITOR> - 0.195
<CAPACITOR>C3204</CAPACITOR> - 0.523
<CAPACITOR>C3205</CAPACITOR> - 0.495
<CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR> - 0.533
<CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> - 0.528

4) Inspect redriver chip for any small hole on top of it - [B]Looks Great![/B]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
I still suspect a problem on USB-C area.
Something blocks the communication between charger and SMC.
And is less probable (but not impossible) to be SMC issue.
See if you get any signals on USB ROM chip, <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
I'm sorry, but what you mean about "USB ROM chip signal"?

<CHIP>U2890</CHIP>
Pins:1-2-3-5-7-8 = 3.3V
Pin 6 - 0.23V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
You should check with o-scope.
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are both connected there.
If no activity detected, something still wrong with USB-C area...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message: I don't see external pull-up resistor on it, so must check on o-scope...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - 5.20v
threads.message:
I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and everything works.

Thank you for the hints.
